135486392.review: The game clearly has some inspiration from Dorfromantik.Here are what I like about the game:[list][*]Simple tutorial[*]Simple control[*]Music is very relaxing[*]Simple crafting system[*]Day/night cycle is reasonable long[*]Can freely choose which tile to place next.[/list]What I don't like as of now, maybe the dev can fix/improve it in the future:[list] [*]Getting water is quite tricky since each water/plain tile only has 2 spots for water gathering. The cooldown time for the next gathering is long. Could be better if I can gather water more often from 1 tile.[*]No option to quick dismantle all building pieces at once while using the hammer. Also should add an option to edit the placement of the building pieces with the hammer. [/list]

135337187.review: Above Snakes is a a sandbox survival crafting game that has an interesting concept to it, building your own world/map as you go. No two maps will be the same and I find that to be a challenge! Creating your own map is like putting puzzle pieces together that will fit your gaming style. You can make certain resources harder to obtain or even easier depending on where you place the map square. It is a promising game with an interesting map building concept. I'll be keeping my eye on this game for full release!

137525804.review:
Demo for a game released 25 May 2023. There's more than enough game here to know if this is your jam, although the demo does cap out just when the pace starts picking up and things start coming together.

Above Snakes is a pretty chilled isometric crafting survival game, heavily inspired by games such as Don't Starve. Unlike Don't Starve, however, the game is not too taxing and has no real time pressure, which suits me just fine. :-)

Some of the screen shots make the game look a bit like a puzzler, but the gameplay arc is more about collecting resources you pick up walking around the isometric map and then crafting things with them.

You accumulate exploration points by collecting stuff, which enables you to discover new tile types (biomes) over time, and then place them on the world map. This does give a nice sense of ownership in creating your environment, although the main strategic element here is just to ensure you have a diversity of biomes close to your main base to save you from having to walk too far to collect recipe components.

There is some very light questing and story, mainly serving to provide some direction to incentivise building new stuff and exploring further afield.

I'm looking forward to the main game, and can see myself sinking quite a few casual hours pottering around in it and exploring new biomes as they unlock.

135523547.review:
[h1] Len's Island meets Dorfromantik! [/h1]

It's like if Len's Island and Dorfromantik were one game, with an extra focus on survival and crafting.
Pleasantly surprised with how good the game feels to control, although "aiming" where I am swinging my axe or shooting an arrow from my bow takes some getting used to. 
The prologue does not take long to reach its end, but you're free to continue "expanding" your map and building cozy little cabins.
I'm looking forward to seeing the full release!

135716487.review:
Needs more polish and playtesting.
You are told to build a house before you build a bed.
But you can't sleep without building a bed because inexplicably the bed you woke from doesn't work.
So you can run out of stamina to do anything -- including build anything -- before you build a bed that you didn't think you'd need.
135716487.developer_response: Thank you for your feedback. We agree that you should be able to sleep before building your house fully, so we'll make the beds in the other buildings available as well to sleep in.

135540057.review: I'm a sucker for cozy crafting / exploration games, so between the unique aesthetic and world-building mechanic, this one intrigued me.  If you're already familiar with this kind of game, you can burn through the prologue very quickly (under an hour) - my experience was that it played very smooth, the art style is reminiscent of other indie titles, and I love the "get better at the skills you use" mechanic a la Valheim or Skyrim.  It's very much a "relax and enjoy" style of game which you can play for a few and then stop, or succumb to the mental gymnastics of "just one more tile and I'll stop."  I'll be watching for the full release!

135721780.review:
Above Snakes is a really interesting take on an otherwise crowded genre, and it's done pretty well.

Pros:
Really interesting and well integrated Carcassonne-type map building
Solidly built survival game overall
Houses are fun to build
Beautiful artstyle

Cons:
Combat is very simplistic
Some recipes are annoying to get (fabric)
Not many original ideas when it comes to the survival mechanics (except for sanity, I'm very intrigued about that)
Dialogue is pretty subpar (this is minor)

Overall, this is a really promising game. I've seen all of the survival and combat mechanics before, so there's nothing new there, but the map building aspect is really well done, I can see it adding some strategy to the full game when you want to keep things relatively close together. The combat feels clunky. I think you're locked into animations for a little bit too long, and the enemies are really forgiving with their attacks, making combat feel simultaneously tedious and really easy. I am a little worried that after you've played for a while and the novelty of the map tiles wears off you'll be left with a pretty basic survival game.

Now, all of this is from 1 hour of a demo with 3 biomes, 2 enemies, and less than 20 crafting recipes, so I can't speak on the full game at all. A couple original enemies would fix all of the problems I have with the game. As a demo goes, this is fantastic, I highly recommend it to anyone who's just a little interested (it's free, you have nothing to lose) I'll keep an eye on this game and I'll probably pick it up when it comes out.

Good work, Square Glade! You have made me a fan.

(Why is it called above snakes? What does that mean??)

135594944.review: Enjoyed this game, was sorry when it was over.... for now

138984764.review:
Great free version of Above Snakes to try out to see if you will enjoy the full game.

I played the Demo when it was out in a Next Fest some time ago.
Sorry, but I don't remember when that was late 2021 or early 2022 maybe?

Anyhow- the Demo was really rough, but the game has come a long way since then.
Default kb/m controls are a bit clunky, but you can rebind keys to suit your preferences and needs. 
Controller works nicely- always nice to have a choice.

Very unique artstyle, quite pleasant and colorful. 
Survival is not difficult like The Long Dark or Green Hell, but you do need to make sure you are monitoring your food, water, sanity and rest need meters.
The zombies are not overwhelming during the day or early evening- but nightfall brings them out. 
You'll need to practice your dodge rolls and make sure you keep crafting better tools/weapons as you can.

The bees HURT. Owwwwwwwie.
You can whack a deer with an axe to kill it(if you can corner it where it can't get away).

Above Snakes: Prologue is a great way to try the game at no cost to see if it "clicks" for you.
If you are looking for "hardcore" survival, this probably isn't going to be it, though you can die in many interesting and gruesome ways. It will be good for people who really like crafting and crafting and crafting and gathering and gathering and gathering and building and building and building. Difficulty progression feel good- it gets slightly more difficult as you progress, but never overwhelming.

Try this before you buy the full game. You can't do everything here that the full game allows, but it's a good tutorial before starting the full game, or a good Demo to see if the game works for you.

137032094.review: The gameplay loop is fundamentally boring for me. It mainly boils down to collecting random resources until you can expand the map just to get dry dialogue and tasks given to you, rinse, and repeat. Bad quests, vapid survival elements, and lackluster exploration isn't a good mix.

137769759.review: Cool intro into the game and it's mechanics. Can't wait for the full version. My only gripe is that the day/night cycles are way too short. I had to rushing home so much. Often before I had the chance to really do gathering and such. So, if nothing else, please make the day cycle longer or at least make it a slider to be adjusted by the player.

136414534.review: I like the concept, however without multiplayer these sorts of grind-survival games are too much of a chore for my taste.

136064285.review:
Valheim and Don't Starve mixed together.
Very cool concept, looking forward towards the full game release!

Please make the rolling/evading with combat more fluid. Feels very clunky with those pauses while you are locked in place after each hit you make and can't move.  "V Rising" combat doesn't have this problem.

137557377.review: It's a great twist on the survival isometric game. The story progresses nicely too. If you want to keep playing and building out the island for a bit (even as it is only a small section of the game) then do not give the fabric to the survivors. Wish listing the full game.

135316991.review: "Above Snakes" is really shaping up to be something really unique and this 2-3 hour long Prologue gives you nice introduction into the game its mechanics.Experience the first parts of Aiyana's story, build you own little shelter, kill some zombies and help the survivors of Corpse Creek!

The literal world building is neat for sure. I've added the game to my wishlist weather I can afford it is a different thing all together. 139173183.review: I wanted to like the game.  Really here is a lot to like.  But, your girl moves way too slow.  Also, they should explain how to complete tasks more.  I think they want you to figure it out.  Hunger and thirst drain too fast.  The controls just feel weird with   mouse.  It does feel much better with controller.  But overall the slowness is a no for me.

139505211.review:
feels slow and clunky to search and do things, coz u have to hold in the T or F buttons, it's quite annoying, makes my fingers hurt. 

can't get back loot when u die, kinda unrealistic.

good art, like the idea of the game but not executed that well.

135978145.review:
The game itself has interesting mechanics (instead of exploring an unknown world, you build it yourself by creating terrain tiles), but there are multiple things that make this game a tough sell:

- poor storytelling: the player starts in a nice little cabin with everything they need, but has to create a simple shelter right next to it, then destroy the nice cabin. It feels forced on the user as part of the tutorial, but provides nothing of value and just doesn't feel good. Similarly, some crafting recipes don't really make sense (crafting a pickaxe with only wood, but the final product has a proper blade).
- I cannot see it be challenging or interesting enough to keep it interesting for hours. Quests typically require crafting a specific terrain tile, which means there will be a lot of resource gathering, but there won't be any discoveries: you know what you put, and where you put it. The night can be skipped by sleeping, which can be done either at your shelter or a camp, and zombies are not impressive during the day.
- Last but not least, the game is poorly optimized.  It is a low poly game, but even on low settings it uses more resources than most games I play. A battery killer if you play on a laptop or Steam Deck.

135578747.review: Great game with simple mechanics. It's fun from what we're able to play and has a good story.

137410083.review: Interesting concept, love the wild west.

135998050.review: Enjoyed the game! Can't wait for the full release. :)

135652755.review:
Super fun, few glitches that need to be fixed and I REALLY hope they add a sprint button but otherwise great game. Crafting is good, story line is good enough, cute graphics, fun new take on a survival games. I recommend it if you like board games.

Glitches:

-if a pop up happens while in bag then once you exit bag you wont be able to interact with anything till you reopen/close your bag.
- (Not a glitch but should be fixed) cant/ very difficult to get up on structures if built slightly above ground level, add a staircase or increase the limit on height player can climb cause i shouldn't have to go from just the right angle to get onto a foundation piece in front of my door when its 2 inches above the ground

135539855.review: Really love this game and I'm very impressed with it. The style, the ambiance, and the look are incredible! Building your own world around you, while surviving in it, and fighting zombies? Mind is blown! Can't wait to play the full game when it releases.

138342395.review: Pretty cool game. easy to get started.  Looking forward to full game. Curious where this game is headed

136940458.review: To be just a prologue it is really cool. The mechanics about world creation feel fresh and new. The combat, crafting and survival are great and gameplay is satisfactory and relaxing and the same time. I will for sure spend a lot of hours once the full game is really. Nice job!

136687647.review:

136044892.review: The Prologue part of game brought me a lot of fun and it was relaxing as well. It has a nice balance of (small) challenges regarding survival, exploring and building. I am asking myself if there will be mounts in future since the map will grow bigger and bigger and it will a take very time long to return to the main base (before night). 135889972.review: Laid back and pretty engaging.  I am not going to pretend this is doing something new, but it is a nice game if you are looking for something that isn't crazy intensive but is still engaging and gives you that "accomplishment" feeling.  I will be getting it when i releases.

135728022.review: A solid little crafty explore game.  Pleasant and engaging.  Some pre-release bugs to sort out so watch for comments on the full release.

135610007.review: please update more until it releases so you can make me more addicted to this game and play this game more

135536214.review: Can't wait for the full release

135521181.review:
This really caught me by surprise. I'm not particularly big on survival games; I have a few I like but I wouldn't say it's a genre I'm invested in. That being said, the prologue certainly gave me a good experience. I didn't really have much that I got stuck on, and at no point did I feel like the game was holding my hand too tightly, or letting me go without any form of guidance too easily. 

Basic experimentation early on with the controls, what things you can/can't do, and the general first two or three missions gave me all I needed to complete the prologue and continue playing for another hour just expanding, experimenting, and so on.

Wishlisted the full version for its May release with the intent to purchase on or near the release date. This is a great survival-style game for people not interested in diving too far in to that genre.

135513997.review: The game still needs a little work, but it was a very fun prologue and I wishlisted it.

135466937.review: The game is enjoyable and it's a more "relaxed and at your own pace" kind of survival game. I recommend it.Personally, I prefer survival with more intermediate steps in crafting/production. It's a bit jarring for me that, for example, 3 twigs makes an axe but that's not exactly a game breaker. I understand how that might not really work in the design or maybe even in spirit of the game.I will most probably be purchasing this for myself on release, the cost permitting. Otherwise when I'm able.

135332407.review: Very atmospheric and easy-going game. Loving the music, the artstyle, story and the world-building. Looking forward to the full game!

138469390.review:

Problems:

135808633.review: The prologue serves as a nice introduction to the game. In some ways, this game reminds me of Len's Island. However, I would suggest improving the graphics, such as providing an option to reduce the particle effects, which can be quite demanding on a mid-range PC. While the idea of assembling the map is great, it may take away from the game's sense of intrigue. 8/10

135494610.review:
Very laid back, almost casual, "open world" sandbox crafter with a  few bugs in this prologue (demo) version.  This is my second go round with this, and I remember having a few issues then, but not sure if these are the same ones or not.  Note that one bug basically halts progress unless you're willing to make some compromises.

1) At some point the workbench becomes unusable. You can stand next to it or move it somewhere else, but no prompt appears meaning you can't use or upgrade it.  Only solution to this is to leave it and build a new one - perhaps...  I didn't try it, so not 100% sure this is the fix.

2) Moving the campfire caused an issue where I could stand where it was previously and get the unlit fire icon to pop-up. I could use it at the new location, but whenever I walked over the old location the icon would appear.

3) Some menus don't work with the controller at all - when researching or creating a new world tile, you can't use the controller to switch between the category types - have to grab the mouse to do it.

4) After placing the platforms to build the new house, I found I was unable to actually get on top of the platform and since there were no stairs, I'd have to tear down the entire thing and build it again and hope I could enter.  However, I ended up placing another platform adjacent to, but outside, the house and putting my bed on that.

I'm undecided on whether or not [i]I'll[/i] get the completed game, but this will definitely appeal to quite a few.

135472319.review: Very promising. The tile placing mechanic is a refreshing mode of progression and feels like a natural fit for the survival genre. Inventory management and general play felt great on controller. Visual clarity in the environment makes foraging less eye straining than it can often be. Definitely worth the time to see if the full game will be for you.

135579131.review:
The trailers don't actually show this it seems like, nor screenshots, but this is a ZOMBIE SURVIVAL GAME. 

However, it's pretty well done and I'd recommend anybody to give it a look tbh. Building is solid, gameplay is pretty chill mostly. I would buy the full game on sale though if only to spite the developers for not adding ranged weapons to a zombie survival prologue game.

However, I also died because no bow and arrow.

Was an enjoyable time though but why would you not put in a bow and arrow at least, in a zombie survival game? Everyone knows melee combat with zombies is a death sentence in video games.

138115249.review:
Overall, I liked it and am interested in the main game. I've played some tile placing world building types and so far I like the way this works. The story looks promising. 

The cons:
-  The camera controls could be slightly more flexible. I wish there was at least a "diagonal" position added if the camera needs to be in set positions rather than free moving. Having more angles would maybe make it easier to see around trees, particularly in the forest squares. 
- The bow controls are frustrating. I couldn't figure out how to easily switch what I was targeting so trying to aim for something specific, like the beehives, could end up very irritating. 
- The water mechanic is confusing. Even the next day sometimes water spots in the lake can't provide water? I could understand fishing being limited but seems like I should be able to collect more that one jug of water every so often from a given spot particularly if I want to be able to use the garden plots or cook with water.

137529829.review: Very unique game, and a lot of fun. Create your own maps, craft, western zombies, gather resources, great story so far. Will be picking this up when full game comes out. Never thought I would say this but a relaxing horror/zombie game. Maybe created a new genre.

137476268.review:
Great game, although it took a bit getting used to the controls. Not a super fan but it's a minor issue.

Survival mechanics are fairly good, but not overly punishing. Game plays well and is really fun, and you got good options for building your (log) house (walls, floors, roofs, etc.). You only have 1 character, Aiyana. But what matters is the scenery, gameplay and map. The map itself is another major character, gradually expanded as you play by unlocking map tiles that you use to expand the map in however way you wish. You unlock the map tiles by "doing stuff" in the game (kind of like XP in rpgs). As for the prologue, map tiles available are of biome types plain, forest, lake and praerie.

Combat Note: The only hostiles in the Demo version seem to be (given what I found) 2 kinds of undead, so the combat seems a bit simplistic. The full game will likely clarify (and perhaps improve on this).

I've seen pictures of ice and badlands tiles too (from the beta / full game), on their Discord channel. The full game will also feature tons more walls, roofs, and more (plank and stone spotted), by looking at the screenshots shared on their Discord channel - honestly, my mind got a little blown away, because this game initially seemed like just a smaller indie project. Can't wait to see the full game release, personally).

The prologue does have limited content, but it's more than enough to get a proper introduction to most core features. You can also keep on playing after you complete the final Prologue quest.

Overall, I am very positively surprised and will absolutely be getting this game on May 25th. I recommend anyone try out the prologue to see for themselves.

For a free indie game demo - I'm giving this a 9/10, hands down!
It'd be a perfect score if it wasn't for slightly weird controls and some minor bugs with water sources and such. The full game may also introduce issues that I have no opinion about at this point.

135960284.review:
There's something weird going on here. Like.. I want to like it, but the little things add up. 
Nothing explains that you have to hold on trees to collect, I spend a solid 30 seconds f mashing pine needles out of trees losing stamina before I figured it out myself. Its not a long time but its enough that its annoying. 
I thought i soft locked the game by chopping all the trees before I had enough sticks to craft a pick then more trees started poofing into existence, thats good I guess it didnt really feel good though. 
Building feels clumsy. Holding a button to craft-build components and then using them from the inventory is more steps that I want to take to build.
The art direction is ALL over the place. the world feels so painterly, the character models are so blocky. The PC's portrait in dialogue is somewhat cartoony, and the NPC that shows up's portrait is pushing hyperrealism.

Positives, the animations are tight, and the concept is novel. I just think it may be too clunky to set itself apart from a million other games that are doing similar things at the moment.

If that was not enough, my first save just bugged and I needed to do it all the way again... I know it is a early acces but since this is basic the main feature of the game should not be that bugged as it is.

Stable.

Chill sounds.
Core gameplay is good.
Simple enough to turn your brain off & play.

Cons:

136261492.review: Pretty much the same as the demo, but with more polish. Looks like it's ready for release for sure, so if you think you might want to play it when it comes out, this is a great way to get a sneak peak.

135727015.review: actually fun, waiting for the full game

136123475.review: Character pictures look AI generated. As an artist it's kinda hard to look at. (my bad if it's actually drawn by someone). 139625414.review: Got stuck (literally) in starting zone in the house with the green. In "Prologue" demo version. Good demo, guys.

135807691.review:
This is one of those 'I wish I could give a neutral review' reviews. I really like the idea of building your world, even if there is not much unique to the game beyond that, but there are some things that do bug me enough to hope the devs will fix them.

Firstly, controls. Tab to open inventory, but not Tab to close. F to open other menus, but not F to close. Besides that, a lot of things need you to not press but hold buttons for 3-5 seconds. This is inconsistent and unnecessary; so many things take longer than they instinctively should.
Also you can't decline quests, but you have to press F to accept them anyway.

Secondly, writing, both dialogue and tutorials. Dialogue is emotionless and superficial, very much a vessel to push you from objective to objective. This wouldn't be an issue if there wasn't so much of it, and you sometimes have to interact with it by picking meaningless dialogue options. I really don't think they meant to make Jo Ann such an insufferable character, but then they also made the first half of the tutorial you doing her dirty work as she idles, until she ditches you first chance. And then you just find the next group of people to do dirty work for.

The tutorial often forgets the tutoring part. It tell you to collect twigs, but forgets to tell you how (ie walk to a tree and press F). It tells you to collect plant fibre, but neglects to specify you need to hit the ferns with your axe to get some. It tells you to place down a world piece, and then you just need to notice the new button in that corner of the screen that was not relevant before. Cook a Berry Bowl, but no mention of the game having a 'discover recipes by inventing them' mechanic. Gather water, but only in these semi-invisible specific spots.

And lastly, art style dissonance. The overworld has a nice if generic low-poly art style. Character models have a low-poly art style that does not look good up close. But then dialogue portraits are high-quality realistic and detailed. But² then the dialogue portrait for your character is of comparatively far lesser quality, ripped straight from the game banner. You can see this dissonance yourself on the screenshots on the game's store page. Even the seemingly one-off tutorial man who doesn't even have a name ('Hunter's Rest Resident') has a higher-quality portrait than the main character.

Also, I thought my character was crouching. I was convinced I'd glitched the game and got stuck in a non-existent crouch. But after trying the game again after a movement speed update I realised... that's just how she stands and walks with a tool out.

I do hope at least the controls can be improved upon and a tutorial can be added.

136748700.review: it plays / controls like a mobile game. no thanks

135702224.review:
Above Snakes: Prologue

Time spent @ time of review: 4.6 hours

Review Status: Worth Trying 

Let me start off this review with saying, thank you for taking the time to read and remember that this review is for the prologue and not the full game. The thoughts and ideas and suggestions carried within are just views of the writer, which is me. Also be FAIR WARNED that I SUCK AT SPELLING and too lazy to use the SPELL CHECKER!

Above Snakes is an open world survival game that you create over time. It comes with crafting, building, farming, gathering, killing and some questing. If I had to sum up the game rather quickly, it is project zomboid but set in the west with the main character being female.

I really enjoyed the prologue so far. I completed the main objective of it within an hour of game play. I spent the rest of my time playing, building, crafting, killing and expanding the map.

The map is based on tiles that you unlock and place once you get enough exp. Some tiles are specific to other tiles, so a plains tile can not butt right next to a grassland tile, You need to unlock the plains/grassland tile to make the transitions between the two.

You will need to be wise with your tile placement - arrangement  and which ones to place first before the other tiles.

PROS:
1. Cute Game - Pleasing on the eyes
2. Pretty simple to understand directions and advance in game play
3. Crafting simple to understand
4. The ability to build the world how you see fit
5. Easy to understand menus and navigation
6. Enjoyable game play, the possibilities are endless, but in the prologue, it gets repetative quickly
7. Building is nice and easy like pretty much any other game that we have played. Craft the item and place it, with options to rotate.
8. 

CONS:
1. Time Speed - goes very quickly - too quickly to state drains and farming/gathering/etc
2. Controls:
a. Combat controls are terrible - melee fighting is not so bad, but aiming with a bow and arrow is horrid. When mouse pointer is over target, would miss 4 out of 5 arrows with the bow just randomly aiming off in a completely different direction.
b. Movement controls are terrible - the Q and E to turn the camera are backwards, hitting "Q" while running will turn the camera to the right instead of what should be turning left and hitting "E" does the opposite. Doing this actually turns the character and the map at the same time and a few times at the start of the game, made me sick to my stomach. I currently only play in one view, using the "Q" and "E" controls I avoid at all costs.
3. The use of "F" key to do almost everything is annoying. The having to hold the button down to do any sort of crafting is stupid.
4. Building has issues, placing items are nice and easy to do but there are gaps in the in textures. So it looks like there are gaps between the building tiles.
5. Map tiles: Do not line up properly, they stay jagged.
6. Map tiles: They are not polished, you character will get randomly stuck where the tiles dip down like to get the water nodes on the water tiles.
7. Respawn timer of mobs is way to slow
8. Crouching while holding tools or weapons is buggy and weird

Ideas or Suggestions:
1. change the way the camera/player turn using the "Q" and "E" options. I would rather remove the bow from the right click option to make you have to switch between it and the tools and have the holding right down or clicking to turn as a option
2. find a way to make the transition between tiles to be smooth instead of the jagged mess that it is.
3. fix the aiming system to be more accurate
4. change the size of the mouse pointer to not be so large
5. have a option to toggle between walking and running, not just when going into a building
6. remove the crouching when holding tools, it is just not needed or make the option to crouch by a button press and hold like other games
7. Fix the issue on launch of the prologue to remember what language I have picked
8. Fix the issue after launching the game and picking a language to remember that I have understood that the game is this and that there can be flashing lights
9. remove the "" WHITELIST BS "" when trying to exit the game, just makes dislike the game even more. it's like watching a video and the first that comes out of their mouth is ""LIKE & SUB"" and then it is repeated every 5 minutes
10. Add co-op or multiplayer ( player hosted servers? ) Would be so much more fun with friends, which could have the option to up the difficulty of the game with the more people you have playing with you.
11. Add other options for player models. Nothing wrong with a female protaganist, but would like to have customization options.

In conclusion if you have read this far, thanks I guess. I really enjoyed the prologue, even with things I found to be wrong or annoying to me. I am looking forward to the release of the game and plan on buying it.

135607996.review:
[h1]Above Snakes: Prologue - A Unique Twist on Survival Games[/h1]

[b]Introduction[/b]

Above Snakes: Prologue is an immersive prologue about an apocalyptic event in a fictional version of the Wild West. The game stands out from other survival games as the world is not generated procedurally, but instead, you generate it yourself by placing isometric tile world pieces. In this review, we'll take a closer look at the game's features and gameplay.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The gameplay in Above Snakes: Prologue is unique and refreshing. As a player, you start your journey in the small lumberjack settlement of Hunter's Rest and begin crafting the world around you. You determine the landscape of this world inspired by the Wild West and dictate how it will unfold before you. Craft, cook, hunt, and fish to help the people of Hunter's Rest. You can also advance in leatherworking, cloth weaving, and other professions to create the best survival supplies for your adventure.

One of the most interesting aspects of the game is the isometric world made of world pieces, which is created by the player throughout their journey. This adds a new layer of strategy to the game, as you must plan out the placement of each piece to ensure you have enough resources to survive.

The deep base building system is another great feature of the game. You can invest your resources into your very own cabin and establish a base for defense and shelter. The extensive outdoor and indoor assets make it possible to create a unique and personalized base that fits your playstyle.

[b]Pros and Cons[/b]

One of the game's biggest pros is its uniqueness. Above Snakes: Prologue offers a refreshing twist on the survival game genre, and the isometric world building is a great addition. The game also has full controller support, key and button rebinding, and accessibility options like disabling camera shake, smooth camera movements, and photosensitive mode.

However, the game is still in its early stages, and there is not much content available in the prologue. It's difficult to determine the game's full potential without experiencing more of it.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Above Snakes: Prologue is a promising game that offers a unique twist on the survival game genre. The game's isometric world building and deep base building system are standout features. The game's accessibility options are also a welcome addition. However, with limited content available in the prologue, it's difficult to determine the game's full potential. Overall, I would love to get my hands on this game to delve further into it and give it a better review. From what I've seen so far, I would recommend this game to fans of survival games who are looking for a new and refreshing experience.

135610691.review:
Aaahhh.... close to being good. It's not exactly terrible though, balancing is all over the place which is one of the major issues. It takes 6 hits to chop down a tree, 8 to mine stone and then... 21 hits to get fibre from a bush... yes a bush...

Now I also was only able to play half an hour because of the next major issue... completely froze and rebooted my pc multiple times! I've seen similar comments about this and sadly there is something going on with this game that does not work well with some pc builds. 

The balancing i'm sure is something that will be, if it already hasn't been, looked at but until I can be confident it will not trash my pc I wont go near this and I would recommend you do your research to see if this has been fixed before you load it up...

138958928.review:
I was pretty excited for this as I followed it on Twitter for some time. However, it makes a boring impression. Unfortunately, I can't put my finger on the problems I have with this pologue. Maybe it's the clunky animations, the uninspired tile design, the slow pace of the story in the beginning (which is obvious though as this is a demo and as you can't just explore before you actually build some stuff). Any crafting necessary seemed tedious. The biggest problem I have, though, is the boring, in a bad way mesmerizing Soundtrack which makes you asleep. Maybe it suits the lostness of the setting, but it wasn't encouraging for me at all. 

I hope that some of the stuff is different or becomes irrelevant in the full title, yet I can hardly imagine that since this Prologue even got an update recently to feel close to the full release.

135417646.review: Very atmospheric and easy-going game. Loving the art style, story and the world-building. definitely an instant buy once it releases

136090215.review: It's good that I played the prolouge and didn't buy the whole game. Because while the prolouge is ok, its already showing the outline of an extremly grindy game where you have to do a bunch of boring resource collecting and walking around doing unnecessary filler until you can get to the actual story, which isn't particularly good either. Also why tf do actions have a little bar that you have to fill up everytime you want to do anything? There is a reason why no other game does this and the reason is that it just wastes time. The cool and new thing about this game are the world pieces and being able to make your own environments. But these positives are far outweighed by the boring groundwork that was laid here.

135784578.review:
If Legend of Mana and Project Zomboid had a baby, this would be it.

There's the world building of Legend of Mana, and the play style and over all feel of Project Zomboid in the character animations and general graphics/layout as well as the combat.

However much like a baby, this game is still developing, and needs a fair bit of work before it's ready for full release. The menus feel a bit clunky, and the character animation needs some additional frames (esp the movement/run) and the trees rocks just magically regrowing every few minutes is kind of irritating when you're trying to craft a specific landscape near your home.

Overall it's a relaxing game and has potential, looking forward to seeing how it shapes up over the coming months.

- etc.

135769044.review:
At this moment the game isn't ready for release at all.
Most of the time the game is about waiting for progress bar to finish like poor quality MMORPG.
No cool animations, just waiting.
Sometimes it gets absurd and you have to wait for a hidden cooldown to scoop water from a seemingly full lake.
There is no stealth mode, but the main character constantly sneaks, slowly like a turtle.
I usually like games with a slow rhythm, but in this case, the developers were simply too lazy to make beautiful animations for basic game actions, and instead added artificial delays.

I added the full game to the wishlist but I am 100% sure that it will not leave early access in 2023.

137344787.review:
Has a clunky interface with held buttons, management spam, and saw-dust filler playtime-padding. Takes minutes to land in medias res; via double confirms and extra warnings. You have to actually confirm a filled up loading bar to progress. Held key F to interact can be "disabled" in options, but then it's clunky instead and needs two or more prompts to react.

Graphics are nothing to write home about, character looks barely human, camera controls not great, and no automated camera direction. Interior art for houses looks okay. The 2D character art looks better, but noticeably different than the 3D one.

Quests and dialogues are generic to the extreme; "oh, i didn't realize i lost my axe, best you craft your own then, don't you think?" collect 3 twigs to craft axe , now get wood, now build pick axe, now fetch stone etc. There is no good feedback for interaction or crafting. 

While we are doing all that there is a dead zombie lying in the backyard. Maybe that's the scenic route.

135545105.review:
the beta is enough to new players to know the rules of game
however, the CD of drinking water in lake is too long, always be thirsty

136619954.review:
This is an incredibly short demo. About a year ago they distributed alpha builds to content creators, and those builds had a lot more content than this demo. It's so strange that they plastered "This is not available in the Prolouge" on so many things that were previously shown by content creators. The world building aspect seems novel, but there are other more fleshed out games (like Forager) with this same mechanic. The sanity stat seems like a ripoff from Don't Starve. And the fact that this game won't have multiplayer is worrying. Almost every single recent "Open World Survival Craft" games have multiplayer, and if you look at the big names, like Minecraft, Terraria, Don't Starve Together, The Forest, Grounded, Satisfactory, Raft, Project Zomboid, No Man's Sky, Astroneer, ARK, Valheim, Rust... They all have multiplayer. This is the most important aspect that makes them successful. 

I hope they won't flop, but only time will tell.
